attributes.name: @ember-data/model
attributes.description:
In EmberData a Model is a class defining the attributes and relationships of a specific resource type (model name). In this sense it represents a static "schema".

Data for individual resources fetched from your API is presented to the UI via instances of the Models you define.

An instantiated Model is referred to as a record.

When we refer to the ModelClass we are referring to the class definition and the static schema methods present on it.

When we refer to a record we refer to a specific class instance presenting the resource data for a given type and id.

Defining a Model

app/models/person.js 
1
2
3

import Model, { attr, belongsTo, hasMany } from '@ember-data/model';

export default class PersonModel extends Model {
attributes.hasmany:
('person', { inverse: 'friends', async: true }) friends;
 }
 ```

 ### modelName convention

 By convention, the name of a given model (its `type`) matches the name
 of the file in the `app/models` folder and should be lowercase, singular
 and dasherized.

@ember-data/model.name: attr
belongsTo
hasMany

Model.name: eachAttribute

params.name: binding
params.description: the value to which the callback's `this` should be bound

Model.description:
Given a callback, iterates over each of the types related to a model,
invoking the callback with the related type's class. Each type will be
returned just once, regardless of how many different relationships it has
with a model.
Model.name: eachRelatedType

params.name: binding
params.description: the value to which the callback's `this` should be bound

Model.description:
Given a callback, iterates over each of the relationships in the model,
invoking the callback with the name of each relationship and its relationship
descriptor.
Model.name: eachRelationship

params.name: binding
params.description: the value to which the callback's `this` should be bound

Model.name: eachTransformedAttribute

params.name: binding
params.description: the value to which the callback's `this` should be bound

Model.name: inverseFor

Model.description: Returns the name of the model class.

typeForRelationship

return.description: the type of the relationship, or undefined

Model.description:
Create should only ever be called by the store. To create an instance of a
`Model` in a dirty state use `store.createRecord`.

   To create instances of `Model` in a clean state, use `store.push`
